commit_message:
Py3: fix serial console output

The compute API expects the serial console output to be a string,
attempting to use a regex to remove some characters. This will fail
as we are returning a byte array.

Also, since the API is expected to return the console output as a
string, the compute nodes may just return a string as well.

Closes-Bug: #1591996
Partially implements blueprint: nova-python3-newton

Change-Id: I5d3097f1d30f3b3568a5421e0d68aaf0797c850a

commit_message:
Update hacking to global-requirements value

The existing version is failing open, which can cause errors to show up.

Omit the "other-requirements.txt"

The plugin needs to omit the "other" requirements files when
indexing python packages.

Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Spec for running overcloud nodes reboot

Change-Id: Ib89da68e0d8cf1f4498b2f275bcb5ce6a555bf72
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/81/224481/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================= Rebooting Overcloud Nodes ========================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/overcloud-nodes-reboot We need a way how to reboot Overcloud nodes in a graceful way. Problem Description =================== Some of minor updates of overcloud nodes may require node reboot to take an effect. Most typical example is applying security kernel update on all overcloud nodes - after installing a new kernel, each node has to be rebooted. By using UpdateDeployment resource in heat templates we are now able to update packages on each node, but once packages are updated there is no mechanism which would allow us to do soft reboot of the updated node so the node can't be automatically rebooted after update. Proposed Change =============== Overview -------- A very similar mechanism used for doing package update could be used for node reboot: updating of a heat parameter would trigger update action of a resource representing reboot action. Resource's update action would run a script on its node which would execute system reboot. More detailed description: A new SoftwareDeployment (called e.g. RebootDeployment) representing reboot action would be added to each resource group. RebootDeployment resource would require an input value representing ID of reboot request, this ID could be set by user by setting a heat parameter (e.g. RebootIdentifier). Then updating this parameter would trigger a script during os-collect-config run. This script would check if RebootIdentifier is set and it would run reboot command. Advantage of this approach is that it can be nicely combined with the existing package update action: * Both actions are represented by resources in heat template so by adding dependency of reboot resource on package update resource we make sure that reboot is done only after successful package update (and only if RebootIdentifier parameter is set). * There is already a CLI command for running package updates which uses heat hooks to do rolling updates. The same mechanism can be used to reboot to make sure that all nodes are not rebooted at the same time. Disadvantages of this approach would be: * Reboot is done from inside each node, if reboot gets stuck there is no mechanism to do hard reboot (by restarting node VM in Nova), user is expected to fix the stuck node. * If reboot of a node fails, overcloud stack update fails too and ends in ERROR state. User is expected to fix the failing node and re-run stack-update again (though reboot script will remember if reboot has been already done on a node and re-running stack-update will not cause re-running reboot on already rebooted nodes). Alternatives ------------ * Reboot nodes by an external tool which would connect to each node and run soft reboot. Disadvantage is that it bypasses Heat so it would be difficult to chain it with other operations done by Heat. Security Impact --------------- This change would allow user to reboot overcloud nodes if he has permission to update overcloud heat stack. But such user could bring down whole overcloud by tweaking other heat parameters anyway. Other End User Impact --------------------- Users would be able to do soft reboot overcloud nodes using heat orchestration for this process. Performance Impact ------------------ Rolling reboot process of all nodes may take lot of time during which overcloud stack is in UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS state so other stack changes can't be done during this time. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jan-provaznik Work Items ---------- * Add a new argument ('--reboot') to the existing package update command in python-tripleoclient, if this argument is set by user, a new value for RebootIdentifier will be passed to heat stack-update together with PackageIdentifier. * Add a new CLI command (to keep consistency with package update syntax it should be probably 'openstack overcloud reboot stack', any thoughts?) which will set breakpoints on all overcloud nodes and then run heat stack-update with a new RebootIdentifier parameter. Same as package update this command will be interactive and during stack-update user will be prompted for removing another breakpoint(s). An alternative to adding a new command would be extending the existing 'openstack overcloud deploy' command but reboot argument shouldn't be mixed with any other arguments related to stack-change (e.g. user couldn't pass '--compute-scale' together with '--reboot' argument) * Define new SoftwareDeployment and SoftwareConfig resources representing reboot action in heat templates. * Create a reboot script triggered on node (this can be part of heat templates similar to package update script). Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Reboot would be an optional feature not necessarily required for deploying overcloud. This feature could be tested in CI by updating overcloud stack with the RebootIdentifier parameter and check that nodes are really rebooted. Documentation Impact ==================== * The new heat parameter would be documented in heat templates. * Usage of reboot command would be documented in python-tripleoclient. References ========== * package update SoftwareConfig (reboot would be similar): https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/extraconfig/tasks/yum_update.yaml

commit_message:
image list: Add Checksum column

The checksum could potentially be useful for spotting duplicated images or
checking if images with the same name are identical or different.

Closes-Bug: #1602073

Change-Id: Ia0c41970c846d550de14297e18bc738e847e5a3b

commit_message:
Pass security group id to novaclient

In RemoveServerSecurityGroup we currently pass the entire security
group object, which results in TypeError in novaclient.
Added unit test case to test command 'openstack server remove
security group -h <server> <group>'

Change-Id: I6d486403a83804c3a30d6f89d2cf7f64f09797c6
Closes-Bug: 1590883

commit_message:
Add network-topolopy support

Add a new api about network-topolopy in openstackclient
It is the intention for OSC to collect data from existing
REST APIs

Change-Id: I23709ee906555d773c3efeb094aef50587732a1b
Related-Bug: #1586584
Implements: bp network-topology-support
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/07/338807/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =============== device topology =============== Network v2 device topology list -------------------- List Device Topology for network This command retrieves information about device topology. Useful for admins who need a quick way to get the virtual device topology about all associated networks. List specifically returns the number of total devices such as instances, routers, free_ports that connect to every network. .. program:: device topology list .. code:: bash os device topology list [--project <project>] .. option:: --project <project> List device topology of given project (name or ID) device topology show -------------------- Show network device topology details This command retrieves information about device topology. Useful for admins who need a quick way to get the virtual device topology and details for a specific network. This command will return information about device topology for the network as a whole, and return availability information for each individual device within the network as well. .. program:: device topology show .. code:: bash os device topology show <network> .. _device_topology_show-network .. describe:: <network> Show device topology for a specific network (name or ID)

commit_message:
Optimise pip install tasks

Unlike the Ansible apt module, the Ansible pip module does not
recognise a with_items list and process all the items at once.

To optimise the pip install tasks, this patch replaces the use
of with_items with a join filter so that the pip install task
does an install with all the packages in a list, ensuring that
the execution is one action instead of many.

Change-Id: I370c407fb77855fa5843d3ecbb608e94932e3447
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_swift refs/changes/19/343719/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Update Ironic VM network connection
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-11 11:24:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/9b9d914fcdd87dde8a8bd7ee3b6f16c68828a2ac', 'message': 'Update Ironic VM network connection

When VM is dirrectly connected to OVS (current setup) there is no port
in OVS when VM is in powered off state. Since Ironic plug port to
network when VM is in powered-off state. Port should be present in OVS
even when VM is powered-off.

This patch adds additional network bridge called br-$VM_NAME for each
VM. Adds additional interface ovs-$VM_NAME which is added to both OVS
and br-$VM_NAME. And configures VM NIC in br-$VM_NAME instead of direct
connection to OVS switch.

Now connection looks like:

               Linux Bridge         OVS
 --------       -----------       ---------
 | vm-1 | <-->  | br-vm-1 | <---> | br-bm |
 --------       -----------       ---------

Change-Id: I317dd9429684a14d16ecf2887d45c2b014e36a84
Implements: blueprint ironic-ml2-integration
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-12-16 16:00:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/b23d59816cb15928792a9947778ec73bb39fbd06', 'message': 'Update Ironic VM network connection

'}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2016-01-19 09:25:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/e386d881e4bbe02e75393fc5c99754eab0cd647e', 'message': 'Update Ironic VM network connection

When VM is dirrectly connected to OVS (current setup) there is no port
in OVS when VM is in powered off state. Since Ironic plug port to
network when VM is in powered-off state. Port should be present in OVS
even when VM is powered-off.

This patch adds additional network bridge called br-$VM_NAME for each
VM. Adds additional interface ovs-$VM_NAME which is added to both OVS
and br-$VM_NAME. And configures VM NIC in br-$VM_NAME instead of direct
connection to OVS switch.

Now connection looks like:

               Linux Bridge         OVS
 --------       -----------       ---------
 | vm-1 | <-->  | br-vm-1 | <---> | br-bm |
 --------       -----------       ---------

Change-Id: I317dd9429684a14d16ecf2887d45c2b014e36a84
Partial-bug: #1526403

connection to OVS switch.

commit_message:
Update Ironic VM network connection

When VM is dirrectly connected to OVS (current setup) there is no port
in OVS when VM is in powered off state. Since Ironic plug port to
network when VM is in powered-off state. Port should be present in OVS
even when VM is powered-off.

This patch adds additional network bridge called br-$VM_NAME for each
VM. Adds additional interface ovs-$VM_NAME which is added to both OVS
and br-$VM_NAME. And configures VM NIC in br-$VM_NAME instead of direct
connection to OVS switch.

Now connection looks like:

               Linux Bridge         OVS
 --------       -----------       ---------
 | vm-1 | <-->  | br-vm-1 | <---> | br-bm |
 --------       -----------       ---------

Change-Id: I317dd9429684a14d16ecf2887d45c2b014e36a84
Partial-bug: #1526403

commit_message:
Preserve data type when parsing MySQL configs

The data type information was lost in conversions.

IniCodec should deserialize Python objects (like other codecs).
guestagent_utils.to_bytes should return byte values as ints.

* The IniCodec is also used by Cassandra.
  Tested with both MySQL and Cassandra scenario tests.

Change-Id: Ibb703b3db6814fc0c9ea4c6d96399f6c881cea03
Closes-Bug: 1599656

deleted_lines: self.assertEqual('1048576', guestagent_utils.to_bytes('1024K')) self.assertEqual('1073741824', guestagent_utils.to_bytes('1024M')) self.assertEqual('1099511627776', guestagent_utils.to_bytes('1024G'))

commit_message:
Remove Interactive Shell, Simplify CLI arg parsing

- Removed kubernetes interactive shell.  Now running kolla-kubernetes
  without arguments prints the help message.
- Removed a whole bunch of *unused* extraneous command line options.
- Simplifed the global and subcommand arg parsing, making more of it
  rely on default code in cliff.app.App, and using existing methods to
  print help strings.
- Removed a bunch of unused methods from Pathfinder.
- Removed config.py, which was full of cli options, of which not a
  single one was used.  New global options should be defined in
  KollaKubernetesShell.build_option_parser.
- Output of kolla-kubernetes help messages is now much shorter.

instead of openstack upper constraints.

commit_message:
Fix Q_PLUGIN_EXTRA_CONF_FILES usage

Change Q_PLUGIN_EXTRA_CONF_FILES to append to the bash array
rather than set (and overwrite).  This will keep any values
set previously by the user and other plugins.

Change-Id: I2d4d103b7c0912082dc5f8d984f3800d77d2a690
Closes-Bug: #1600664
Signed-off-by: Michael Micucci <micucci@midokura.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-l2gw refs/changes/04/340204/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Q_PLUGIN_EXTRA_CONF_FILES+=(l2gw_plugin.ini)

subject: Kolla-Kubernetes multi-node persistence for Mariadb
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-28 20:32:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes/commit/517c8f27db9c330e9d34fe9b84bf433c900f434c', 'message': 'POC (do no merge): Kolla-Kubernetes multi-node persistence pattern

There's no intention of merging this.  Just want to demonstrate a proof
of concept for discussion.

This patch is a proof of concept which shows how we may support the
configuration and use of kubernetes persistent volumes across storage
providers, including Ceph, AWS, GCE, and host development mounts on the
all-in-one Hyperkube.

Problem Statement: Currently, boostrap and running of kolla containers
requiring persistence will fail on multi-node kubernetes clusters
because the bootstrap using a hostmount may occur on a different node
than the node on which the service pod will run.  Thus, in order to
support multi-node deployments of kolla-kubernetes, we must support
persistent volumes that replication controllers can associate with and
follow pods which may move from one host to another.

Configure kolla-kubernetes for a particular storage provider by editing
'./etc/kolla-kubernetes/kolla-kubernets.yml', and setting the following
'storage_provider: "gce" # host, ceph, gce, aws'.  From here, the
templates should do the right thing, from creating the block storage and
persistent volumes only if necessary (not necessary on AWS which
supports Experimental Persistent Volume Provisioning) and creating the
persistent volume claims.  The templates have already been modified with
conditionals to do the right thing for the jobs and pod definitions.

This patch is also part hack, because of some assumptions in the
existing code, some of which I think I'll submit patches for.
- kolla-kubernetes template processing does not handle more than a
  single document in the stream.  Thus I had to create an
  "kolla-kubernetes template <file>" command using the standard jinja2
  lib instead of the built-in jinja_utils.
- kolla-kubernetes template processing eats newlines in Jinja if/else
  statements.
- kolla-kubernetes: hard-coded: ['kubectl',
  '--server=http://localhost:8080' makes commands fail for anything but
  local hyperkube.  Should just use defaults from kubectl.  Patch to follow.
- kolla-kubernetes On GCE, the mariadb was unable to mount the drive
  that mariadb-bootstrap mounted, until I deleted the mariadb-bootstrap
  job.  This, we'll need to figure out and test on other providers.

Here are the steps to get this going:

pushd kolla-kubernetes
pip install --editable .
popd

export DOCKER_REGISTRY="gcr.io"
export DOCKER_NAMESPACE="your_gcr_project"
export DOCKER_TAG="3.0.0"
export KOLLA_CONTAINERS="mariadb memcached kolla-toolbox keystone horizon"

for i in $KOLLA_CONTAINERS; do
  kolla-build $i --registry $DOCKER_REGISTRY --namespace $DOCKER_NAMESPACE
done
for i in $KOLLA_CONTAINERS; do
  gcloud docker push "$DOCKER_REGISTRY/$DOCKER_NAMESPACE/centos-binary-$i:$DOCKER_TAG"
done

kolla-kubernetes template bootstrap/mariadb/mariadb-disk.sh.j2 | sh
kolla-kubernetes template bootstrap/mariadb/mariadb-pvpvc.yml.j2 | kubectl create -f -
kolla-kubernetes createconfigmaps mariadb
kolla-kubernetes template bootstrap/mariadb/mariadb-job.yml.j2 | kubectl create -f -
kolla-kubernetes run mariadb
kolla-kubernetes run memcached
kolla-kubernetes bootstrap keystone
kolla-kubernetes run keystone
kolla-kubernetes run horizon

^ And now, we should have a fulling working horizon accessable via the
http horizon service

Change-Id: I32968cd4faed5413066af28c25ca32b6e79743ac
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-29 04:29:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes/commit/9ac9fdb01148a46fcba8229fcae7886f0409d2e4', 'message': 'POC (do no merge): Kolla-Kubernetes multi-node persistence pattern

support multi-node deployments of kolla-kubernetes, we must support
persistent volumes that replication controllers can associate with and
follow pods which may move from one host to another.

See ./doc/source/multi-node.rst for the multi-node deployment guide.

commit_message:
Kolla-Kubernetes multi-node persistence for Mariadb

This patch uses the Mariadb service to show how we may support the
configuration and use of kubernetes persistent volumes across storage
providers, including Ceph, AWS, GCE, and host development mounts on
the all-in-one Hyperkube.

Problem Statement: Currently, boostrap and running of kolla containers
requiring persistence will fail on multi-node kubernetes clusters
because the bootstrap using a hostmount may occur on a different node
than the node on which the service pod will run.  Thus, in order to
support multi-node deployments of kolla-kubernetes, we must support
persistent volumes that replication controllers can associate with and
follow pods which may move from one host to another.

See ./doc/source/multi-node.rst for the multi-node deployment guide.

Change-Id: I32968cd4faed5413066af28c25ca32b6e79743ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes refs/changes/15/335215/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {%- set resourceName = "mariadb" -%}{%- if storage_provider == "host" %}{%- else %} persistentVolumeClaim: claimName: {{ resourceName }} {%- endif %}

commit_message:
Add undercloud idempotency test

We need to be testing that the undercloud install is idempotent.
Re-running the undercloud install after the overcloud is deployed
but before the ping test and node count check is performed should
give us reasonable certainty that reinstalling the undercloud won't
horribly break deployed overclouds.

Change-Id: I81f1c1bbf27415d5932c6413a0c2ec6745c77854

In order to not break local name resolution for the fuel environment, we
should rely on dnsmasq to query the upstream servers for us. Because of

commit_message:
Do not add upstream to resolv.conf on master

In order to not break local name resolution for the fuel environment, we
should rely on dnsmasq to query the upstream servers for us. Because of
this, the resolv.conf on the master should only point to the cobbler
dnsmasq instance which is configured with the upstream hosts to use if
the local resolution fails.

Change-Id: I757d89173d98dda419d21ef6132d59f186a97782
Closes-Bug: #1567957

commit_message:
Refactor heat driver create() handler

It helps to improve the readability and
maintanence easier.

Change-Id: Ibd0770ebb2917d910a2115e4695b724b84e029c8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker refs/changes/64/330664/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import copy cfg.IntOpt('scale_cooldown', default=60, help=_("Wait time (in seconds) between consecutive scaling" "operations. During the cooldown period, scaling action" " will be ignored by tacker")), attributes = device['device_template']['attributes'].copy() vnfd_yaml = attributes.pop('vnfd', None) if vnfd_yaml is None: # TODO(kangaraj-manickam) raise user level exception LOG.info(_("VNFD is not provided, so no device is created !!")) return LOG.debug('vnfd_yaml %s', vnfd_yaml) def update_fields(): fields = dict((key, attributes.pop(key)) for key in ('stack_name', 'template_url', 'template') if key in attributes) for key in ('files', 'parameters'): if key in attributes: fields[key] = jsonutils.loads(attributes.pop(key)) # overwrite parameters with given dev_attrs for device creation dev_attrs = device['attributes'].copy() fields.update(dict((key, dev_attrs.pop(key)) for key in ('stack_name', 'template_url', 'template') if key in dev_attrs)) for key in ('files', 'parameters'): if key in dev_attrs: fields.setdefault(key, {}).update( jsonutils.loads(dev_attrs.pop(key))) return fields, dev_attrs fields, dev_attrs = update_fields() def generate_hot_from_tosca(vnfd_dict): parsed_params = dev_attrs.pop('param_values', {}) toscautils.updateimports(vnfd_dict) try: tosca = ToscaTemplate(parsed_params=parsed_params, a_file=False, yaml_dict_tpl=vnfd_dict) except Exception as e: LOG.debug("tosca-parser error: %s", str(e)) raise vnfm.ToscaParserFailed(error_msg_details=str(e)) monitoring_dict = toscautils.get_vdu_monitoring(tosca) mgmt_ports = toscautils.get_mgmt_ports(tosca) res_tpl = toscautils.get_resources_dict(tosca, STACK_FLAVOR_EXTRA) toscautils.post_process_template(tosca) try: translator = TOSCATranslator(tosca, parsed_params) heat_template_yaml = translator.translate() except Exception as e: LOG.debug("heat-translator error: %s", str(e)) raise vnfm.HeatTranslatorFailed(error_msg_details=str(e)) heat_template_yaml = toscautils.post_process_heat_template( heat_template_yaml, mgmt_ports, res_tpl, unsupported_res_prop) return heat_template_yaml, monitoring_dict def generate_hot_scaling(vnfd_dict, scale_resource_type="OS::Nova::Server"): # Initialize the template template_dict = {'heat_template_version': '2014-10-16'} template_dict['description'] = 'Tacker scaling template' parameters = {} template_dict['parameters'] = parameters # Add scaling related resource defs resources = {} outputs = {} # tosca groups # # properties: # min_count: 1 # max_count: 3 # init_count: 2 # members: [VDU1] def _convert_to_heat_scaling_group(group_prp, scale_resource_type): group_hot = {'type': 'OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup'} properties = {} properties['min_size'] = group_prp['min_count'] properties['max_size'] = group_prp['max_count'] properties['desired_capacity'] = group_prp['init_count'] properties['cooldown'] = CONF.tacker_heat.scale_cooldown # TODO(kanagaraj-manickam) all VDU memebers are considered, # and already its converted as custome type template in main # logic and for the same scale_group_type is given in params # so even if there are many VDUs which are not part of scaling # group will be consider for scaling. properties['resource'] = {} properties['resource']['type'] = scale_resource_type # TODO(kanagraj-manickam) add custom type params here, to # support parameterized template group_hot['properties'] = properties return group_hot # groups: # G1: # type: tosca.groups.tacker.ScaleGroup if 'groups' in vnfd_dict: for name, group in vnfd_dict['groups'].items(): if group['type'] == 'tosca.groups.tacker.ScaleGroup': group_prp = _convert_to_heat_scaling_group( group['properties'], scale_resource_type) resources[name] = group_prp outputs[name] = {'value': { 'get_attr': [name, 'outputs_list']}} # tosca policies # # properties: commit_message:
Fix SSL/TLS ciphers/options for HAProxy services

* implement the same SSL/TLS ciphers as for Fuel master node (disable
  WEAK DHE ciphers but leave TLSv1 working: LP#1497195
* remove useless dh_param options because they not needed anymore
* move the ciphers list to the cluster::haproxy parameters and don't
  repeat this list in the several configuration files (DRY)
* prepare for an upgrade and move the options list to global settings
  too (DRY) (TODO)
* ssl_default_ciphers can be changed by end user via hiera

DocImpact
Change-Id: I5e5784521641ea3bbe3c4aa40c581f996b268aad
Closes-Bug: #1594359
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <mmalchuk@mirantis.com>
(cherry picked from commit 996058caddcd57eed9bfc9d92def923ca68cd7e3)

commit_message:
[Tempest] Handle errored shares correctly using recreation logic

If we allow share recreation and get some share errored
making it part of CG, then we fail to create CG snapshot from CG
that owns this share. Because cleanup step was not reached yet.
Therefore, consider this case and delete errored shares immediately.

Change-Id: Ib05598de8fbd1c9a735ca91159f3f5cfb86d8889
Closes-Bug: #1577887

commit_message:
Fixes consistency snapshot creation

This fixes the bug where creation of consistency snapshot would pass
even if the volume is in error state. Also adding unit test to
ensure that the creation of consistency snapshot fails when
volume is in error status.

Closes-Bug: #1592451

Change-Id: I482a7e01f32d72196568348225eb3c77a432a539
Signed-off-by: Nitin Madhok <nmadhok@g.clemson.edu>

This switches the codebase to use only specific d3 (version 4) modules
rather than the entire d3 (v3) package, resulting in a decent shrink
in build size (~75KB reduction).

Change-Id: I9f6a5d039d6340cc28115337bdfb891d15af7057
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-05-28 21:36:49.000000000', 'files': ['app/js/directives/timeline-viewport.js', 'app/js/directives/timeline.js', 'app/js/directives/timeline-dstat.js', 'app/js/filters/seconds-time.js', 'app/js/util/dstat-parse.js', 'package.json', 'app/js/directives/timeline-overview.js'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/stackviz/commit/965e723004e7a0f39f4d9aa51b8fd1fb86513a97', 'message': 'Use d3 modules to reduce build size

This switches the codebase to use only specific d3 (version 4) modules

Change-Id: I9f6a5d039d6340cc28115337bdfb891d15af7057
'}]
commit_message:
Use d3 modules to reduce build size

This switches the codebase to use only specific d3 (version 4) modules
rather than the entire d3 (v3) package, resulting in a decent shrink
in build size (~75KB reduction).

Change-Id: I9f6a5d039d6340cc28115337bdfb891d15af7057
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/stackviz refs/changes/71/319471/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: var d3Scale = require('d3-scale'); var y = d3Scale.scaleLinear(); var currentMid = (+viewStart) + (size / 2);
deleted_lines: var d3 = require('d3'); var y = d3.scale.linear(); var currentMid = viewStart.getTime() + (size / 2);

subject: Configure postfix to use correct hostname
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-14 15:39:42.000000000', 'files': ['tests/noop/spec/hosts/tools/tools_spec.rb', 'deployment/puppet/osnailyfacter/manifests/tools/tools.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/9288dc828f3b55ec6a0745b7d603a561f86a0537', 'message': 'Configure postfix to use correct hostname

Change-Id: Idaeb95f2232db7611f6f2c13b9e22152076acd30
Closes-Bug: #1602239
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <mmalchuk@mirantis.com>
(cherry picked from commit 90d04251e70f675cc020cf253232ed8a05273210)
'}]
commit_message:
Configure postfix to use correct hostname

Change-Id: Idaeb95f2232db7611f6f2c13b9e22152076acd30
Closes-Bug: #1602239
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <mmalchuk@mirantis.com>
(cherry picked from commit 90d04251e70f675cc020cf253232ed8a05273210)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/52/342252/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: service { 'postfix': ensure => running, enable => true, } augeas { 'configure postfix': context => '/files/etc/postfix/main.cf', changes => [ "set /files/etc/postfix/main.cf/mydestination ${::fqdn},localhost", "set /files/etc/postfix/main.cf/myhostname ${::fqdn}", ], notify => Service['postfix'], }

subject: Fix the username value in federated tokens
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-29 18:37:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/8840a273abb57c722655b951904d0ea55f4bd1be', 'message': 'Fix the username value in federated tokens

Currently, in both unscoped and scoped federated tokens, the
username value in the token is equal to the userid and not to
the value of the username in the external identity provider.
This makes WebSSO login to show the userid of the logged-in
user in the Horizon dashboard, whereas before it was showing
the actual user name.

This patch fixes the value of the username in the federated tokens
to be the actual name of the federated user, which will fix the
WebSSO issue as well, since Horizon looks at the username value
and displays that as the logged-in user.

Closes-Bug: #1597101
Change-Id: I33a0274641c4e6bc4e127f5206ba9bc7dbd8e5a8
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-29 23:17:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/e79292153cafda4d251b4df56f14cc9157fefa80', 'message': "Fix the username value in federated tokens

Currently, in both unscoped and scoped federated tokens, the
username value in the token is equal to the userid and not to
the value of the username in the external identity provider.
This makes WebSSO login to show the userid of the logged-in
user in the Horizon dashboard, whereas before it was showing
the actual user name.

This patch fixes the value of the username in the federated
non-Fernet tokens, which will fix the WebSSO issue as well,
since Horizon looks at the username value and displays that as
the logged-in user.

This patch doesn't fix Fernet tokens as information about user's
name is not persisted in the encrypted/compressed payload.
Fix for Fernet will be split out in a different review.

Partial-Bug: #1597101
Partial-Bug: #1482701
Change-Id: I33a0274641c4e6bc4e127f5206ba9bc7dbd8e5a8

commit_message:
Fix the username value in federated tokens

Currently, in both unscoped and scoped federated tokens, the
username value in the token is equal to the userid and not to
the value of the username in the external identity provider.
This makes WebSSO login to show the userid of the logged-in
user in the Horizon dashboard, whereas before it was showing
the actual user name.

This patch fixes the value of the username in the federated
tokens, which will fix the WebSSO issue as well, since Horizon
looks at the username value and displays that as the logged-in user.

Closes-Bug: #1597101
Closes-Bug: #1482701
Change-Id: I33a0274641c4e6bc4e127f5206ba9bc7dbd8e5a8

subject: Optimise pip install tasks
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-18 15:21:01.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/sahara_install.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_sahara/commit/ed6fbb1d84b92afd7bf205554abea03628c02fa7', 'message': 'Optimise pip install tasks

Unlike the Ansible apt module, the Ansible pip module does not
recognise a with_items list and process all the items at once.

To optimise the pip install tasks, this patch replaces the use
of with_items with a join filter so that the pip install task
does an install with all the packages in a list, ensuring that
the execution is one action instead of many.

Change-Id: I9a372286efe2105568f9ef2d29be62d0f8070303
'}]
commit_message:
Optimise pip install tasks

Unlike the Ansible apt module, the Ansible pip module does not
recognise a with_items list and process all the items at once.

To optimise the pip install tasks, this patch replaces the use
of with_items with a join filter so that the pip install task
does an install with all the packages in a list, ensuring that
the execution is one action instead of many.

Change-Id: I9a372286efe2105568f9ef2d29be62d0f8070303
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_sahara refs/changes/17/343717/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: name: "{{ item }}" with_items: "{{ sahara_required_pip_packages }}" name: "{{ item }}" with_items: "{{ sahara_pip_packages }}"

commit_message:
Missing CephClientKey parameter in puppet-ceph-devel and storage-environment

This change adds the CephClientKey parameter to puppet-ceph-devel.yaml
and storage-environment.yaml environment files. This is needed when
--ceph-storage is not passed to the openstack overcloud deploy command
as the tripleo client doesn't generate the keys.

Change-Id: Idfdce190c2ad4ae198fe17474aee19cb76dac5fb
Closes-Bug: #1601864

commit_message:
DVR: handle floating IP reassociation on the same host

The case when floating IP is reassociated from one VM to another
on the same host without doing disassociation, was not properly handled:
l3 dvr agent only checked that the floating address was present on the
device in router namespace and considered floating IP confiigured correctly.
This patch adds fip_mapping to router object so fixed IP change can be
detected and handled.

Closes-Bug: #1599089
(cherry picked from commit b8a2cb813225ae6178f34363cab9a2446d471472)

Conflicts:
	neutron/tests/functional/agent/l3/test_dvr_router.py
Change-Id: I25c23bb9ad7b9a9b90f225f37417142e2304deb8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/40/341840/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(ip_lib, 'IPRule') def test_floating_ip_moved_dist(self, mIPRule): router = mock.MagicMock() ri = self._create_router(router) floating_ip_address = '15.1.2.3' fip = {'floating_ip_address': floating_ip_address, 'fixed_ip_address': '192.168.0.1'} ri.floating_ips_dict['15.1.2.3'] = FIP_PRI ri.fip_ns = mock.Mock() ri.fip_ns.allocate_rule_priority.return_value = FIP_PRI ri.floating_ip_moved_dist(fip) mIPRule().rule.delete.assert_called_once_with( ip=floating_ip_address, table=16, priority=FIP_PRI) ri.fip_ns.deallocate_rule_priority.assert_called_once_with( floating_ip_address) ri.fip_ns.allocate_rule_priority.assert_called_once_with( floating_ip_address) mIPRule().rule.add.assert_called_with(ip='192.168.0.1', table=16, priority=FIP_PRI)

commit_message:
DVR: handle floating IP reassociation on the same host

The case when floating IP is reassociated from one VM to another
on the same host without doing disassociation, was not properly handled:
l3 dvr agent only checked that the floating address was present on the
device in router namespace and considered floating IP confiigured correctly.
This patch adds fip_mapping to router object so fixed IP change can be
detected and handled.

Closes-Bug: #1599089
(cherry picked from commit b8a2cb813225ae6178f34363cab9a2446d471472)

Conflicts:
	neutron/tests/functional/agent/l3/test_dvr_router.py
Change-Id: I25c23bb9ad7b9a9b90f225f37417142e2304deb8

commit_message:
Adding dns service to kolla-kubernetes service list

This patch makes kolla-kubernetes aware of dns service and pod
objects, it also adds new KubeUtils class to utils.py to be able
to extract API server ip address.

Change-Id: I377a22157d0bf2fbe5ff2da17b6eb4e245447b9c
Partially-Implements: blueprint kolla-kubernetes-service-discovery

Changed api service requirements

Watcher-api doesn't need watcher::db class in service requirements,
because it is handled by deps class.

commit_message:
Use versionless keystone endpoint for horizon

According to horizon patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/321640/,
horizon now supports versionless keystone endpoint, so we need
to use versionless endpoint for testing.

Change-Id: Ia176f507f703189caf89371179dd77bc17704e1c
Depends-On: I01120db7cdf31e82c1da45545009df101f69f128

commit_message:
Add assess_status() to base layer as part of workload status

This bakes in the assess_status() to the update-status hook to call
assess_status() on the charms_openstack.charm.OpenStackCharm class.

This has the effect of determining the workload status for the
unit.

Change-Id: Idf9a712f818445ba9f68dccae2d98237eb7f7eee
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-layer-openstack refs/changes/09/342909/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # handle the update-status hook for all openstack charms from __future__ import absolute_import import charms.reactive as reactive import charmhelpers.core.hookenv as hookenv import charms_openstack.charm as charm @reactive.hook('update-status') def update_status(): """Use the update-status hook to run the assess_status() function for the unit. This runs, via the singleton, the assess_status() on the derived class, which is auto-instantiated according the the release. To deactivate this function override the assess_status in the derived class to a NOP. """ charm.OpenStackCharm.singleton.assess_status()

commit_message:
Add hiera support

This change adds hiera support into the scenarios so we can override
items via the common.yaml heira file if need be. This change adds
support for two environment variables with run_tests.sh.

HIERA_CONFIG - full path to the hiera yaml configuration file
MANAGE_HIERA - used to enable/disable writing out a hiera.yaml config
file

Change-Id: Iad0050e09e0cc610e0eadc00e328151e88eee10e

commit_message:
Gracefully handle absence of network_device_mtu option

This option is deprecated and will be removed in Newton. We should be
prepared for that.

Change-Id: I8e6cc99fe70d0c41a705431fb3160e8fccacff10
Related-Bug: #1603493

commit_message:
Use network MTU if network_device_mtu not set

network_device_mtu option is deprecated as of Mitaka. Calico interface
driver should use the passed mtu argument value if the deprecated option
is not set.

Change-Id: I15003f5b96cd615ad21d89fdbc7455097c0321b8
Related-Bug: #1549470
Related-Bug: #1542108
Related-Bug: #1542475

commit_message:
Switching SELinux to enforcing mode

This spec describes why we should run SELinux in enforcing mode and
proposes the changes that are required to get there.

Change-Id: I1a2fb469446a9556ecb9e78c20e3619a8788bce7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/68/108168/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Switching SELinux to enforcing mode ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/tripleo-juno-switching-selinux-to-enforcing-mode On Fedora, tripleo is currently set to run SELinux in permissive mode. Historically, running tripleo in enforcing mode has not been possible because the Fedora SELinux policy has not kept up with the latest upstream changes. Turning SELInux on would have caused devtest to fail. Here we are proposing a way to run SELinux in enforcing mode and a process by which we can update the SELinux policy locally and feed the local changes up to the upstream SELinux policy. Problem Description =================== For added security on most production systems, SELinux runs in enforcing mode on Fedora and RHEL. Currently, devtest defaults to running SELinux in permissive mode. Eventually someone needs to run tripleo in enforcing mode, gather issues that may arise, and fix the issues or file bugs to ask for the upstream SELinux policy to be updated. Right now that process is happening towards the end of cycles. We do not want to be be in a position where we are asking for SElinux policy updates and or making fixes to TripleO at the end of cycles. There is not enough time to chase SELinux bugs at the end of cycles and have the fixes be reviewed and approved. And it is also insufficient time to ask for updates to the upstream SELinux policy. We would like to be able to detect SELinux issues earlier in the development process. SELinux issues can happen in many ways: when new services/elements are added to tripleo-image-elements, when a service begins to use a new port, when the structure of /mnt/state is changed or reorganized, or when data directories are placed in a non-standard location that is recognized by SELinux. Setting SELinux to run in enforcing mode by default will allow us to detect when changes to the upstream SELinux policies are needed. Ideally we should be detecting SELinux issues when developers test their changes locally and have a fix or a custom policy included for them when they land their patches for review. If necessary, the developer can then also file a BZ upstream to ask for the policy to be updated. Not all SELinux issues will need a policy update. Not all developers work on Fedora or RHEL. This means the fedora overcloud tripleo-ci jobs will need to catch the remaining issues. And when failures occur, developers need to have sufficient information to diagnose the problem and determine if it is due to SELinux. A custom policy to fix and SELinux issue can be automatically generated from /var/log/audit/audit.log. A developer should be able to take the auto-generated custom policy and add it to tripleo-image-elements as a hot fix until the upstream SELinux policy can be updated fix the problem. SELinux can be difficult to decypher for the uninitiated. In general, we would like to increase SELinux knowledge for all tripleo developers. Not everyone needs to know every single intricate detail of how SELinux works. We should have more than one person with a base set of knowledge. To that end, there needs to be some documentation for developers detailing how to address SELinux issues within the tripleo context. Proposed Change =============== * Update CI jobs to save /var/log/audit/audit.log and other diagnostic information (ps -efZ output) from test runs. This information will help developers decide how to fix the problem. A custom policy that can be used as a hot fix should be automatically generated if errors are detected in audit.log. * Create a SELinux developer guide. The guide will detail what a developer should do if SELinux is the cause of a failure. There are three primary ways SELinux issues are fixed: correct the file security contexts, enabling a selinux boolean to allow certain actions, and adding a custom policy as a hot fix. The guide will address these issues and also talk about how to file bugs to launchpad and bugzilla and what details to include. * Build developer friendly scripts to make it easier to fix SELinux issues and to make the code easier to understand. This is already in progress with these patches: https://review.openstack.org/99242, support for correction of file contexts https://review.openstack.org/106908, support for selinux booleans https://review.openstack.org/106909, support for compiling and installing custom policy files * Patch upstream so that we get to a state where devtest passes when SELinux is in enforcing mode. * Send an email out to list indicating that selinux with be enabled in x days. They should review developer guide if they hit an SELinux issue. SELinux issues should be fixed as they are found during development. If the issue is found by tripleo-ci, then developers are responsible for fixing it or finding help to fix it. * If a SELinux issue is fixed by using a custom policy, a bug should be filed upstream to ask for the SELinux policy to be updated. * Set SELinux to run in enforcing mode in devtest and in tripleo-ci. We could enable it in devtest first before enabling it in tripleo-ci. Alternatives ============ We could leave SELinux running in permissive mode, and flag builds where an error is detected in /var/log/audit/audit.log. In permissive mode some errors do get logged to audit.log, but not all. Enforcing mode is required to catch all errors. Security Impact =============== We would be helping to improve security be keeping the SELinux policy up to date. Other End User Impact ===================== This change is transparent to end users. Performance Impact ================== None Other Deployer Impact ===================== If they are running tripleo, then they would also need to be notified when this change is made. Developer Impact ================ All developers will now be responsible for resolving SELinux issues. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: rwsu Other contributors: Most welcomed. Work Items ---------- * Add information to help diagnose SELinux issues in tripleo-ci. A suggested custom policy should be produced if errors are detected in /var/log/audit/audit.log. * Create a SELinux developer guide suited to tripleo. * Build scripts/infrastructure to make working with SELinux easier. * Submit and merge patches to tripleo to get to a state where devtest and tripleo-ci can pass if SELinux is set to enforcing mode. * Give advanced warning to developers when SELinux will be in enforcing mode. * Switch SELinux to enforcing mode. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= First, verify devtest passes if selinux-permissive is removed from Fedora NODE_DIST. Then we would move to verifying that tripleo-ci can pass if Fedora jobs is set to run in enforcing mode. This can be done by submitting a patch or through the experimental-tripleo pipeline. Documentation Impact ==================== Update the tripleo user manuals and developer guides to point to the SELinux developer guide. References ========== 1. http://openstack.redhat.com/SELinux_issues 2. http://docs.fedoraproject.org/en-US/Fedora/19/html/Security_Guide/ch09.html

subject: Align Legacy Workflows: Launch Instance
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-15 22:30:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/0a2e37d93ef2e5e77e4e5a18fa1b80cc7116f26e', 'message': "Align Legacy Workflows: Launch Instance

Aliging the legacy workflows with the new modern workflows.

Though it has been deprecated, Legacy Launch Instance was the
clear choice in the first workflow to tackle, because it exists
in a modern form now, that can easily be compared against the
legacy for functionality and evolution of layout.

Legacy templates have been left in place to allow existing
workflows to continue to work until they can be updated.

Nuances:
Legacy workflows only had a concept of 'help text' which was
allotted the entire 1/2 of the modal window at all times.

Modern workflows have 3 concepts of 'help text':
 * Step Description - above the form
 * Help Block - hidden in the help panel
 * Extras - Graphs and other useful information that takes
   up 1/4 of the modal width when used.

Closes-bug: #1593001
Change-Id: Id0487cb854fcbcd04970b52a19d0b2c57db68a4c
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-15 23:13:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/4a1111fe9fb6fe5e533ff0fbf2475e0ee0e696f3', 'message': "Align Legacy Workflows: Launch Instance

Though it has been deprecated, Legacy Launch Instance was the
clear choice in the first workflow to tackle, because it exists
in a modern form now, that can easily be compared against the

Legacy templates have been left in place to allow existing

Nuances:
Legacy workflows only had a concept of 'help text' which was
allotted the entire 1/2 of the modal window at all times.

Modern workflows have 3 concepts of 'help text':

 * Help Block - hidden in the help panel
 * Extras - Graphs and other useful information that takes

commit_message:
Align Legacy Workflows: Launch Instance

Aligning the legacy workflows with the new modern workflows.

Though it has been deprecated, Legacy Launch Instance was the
clear choice in the first workflow to tackle, because it exists
in a modern form now, that can easily be compared against the
legacy for functionality and evolution of layout.

Legacy templates have been left in place to allow existing
workflows to continue to work until they can be updated and
any plugins that might be making use of it.

Nuances:
Legacy workflows only had a concept of 'help text' which was
allotted the entire 1/2 of the modal window at all times. The
workflows are now responsive with toggle navigation for small
screens.

Modern workflows have 3 concepts of 'help text':
 * Step Description - above the form
 * Help Block - hidden in the help panel
 * Extras - Graphs and other useful information that takes
   up 1/4 of the modal width when used.

partial-bug: #1593001
Change-Id: Id0487cb854fcbcd04970b52a19d0b2c57db68a4c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/53/330253/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add Python 3.5 classifier and venv

Now that there is a passing gate job, we can claim support for
Python 3.5 in the classifier. This patch also adds the convenience
py35 venv.

Change-Id: Idfd9818434481ede85ff8e746893ac7e27fcb333
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr refs/changes/91/341891/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py35,py34,py27,pep8

commit_message:
Use {name} instead of ZUUL_PROJECT in ansible role post_test_hook

Otherwise it shows 'openstack/$PROJECT', making tests to fail as
the path does not exist.
e.g.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/342099/ , patchset 18.

{name} just contains the project name being tested, so just use it.

Change-Id: Ib41e31eba87c863723ede7b89ca81a4c871ad5e5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/97/343597/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $BASE/new/$(basename $ZUUL_PROJECT)/tests/hooks/post_test_hook.sh

commit_message:
Update the lookup plugin to force dep ordering

This change ensures that the dependency file ordering
for requirements file is kept intact for all fot the discovered
file used to build the repo environment.

Change-Id: I36d2044965c8a0809a417083c3f24c406b5a36c9
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins refs/changes/84/342984/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'global-requirements.txt', return_list = self._filter_files(self.file_names, 'txt') for file_name in return_list: base_name = os.path.basename(file_name) if base_name in REQUIREMENTS_FILE_TYPES: index = REQUIREMENTS_FILE_TYPES.index(base_name) return_list.remove(file_name) return_list.insert(index, file_name) else: print return_list for file_name in return_list:

commit_message:
Clean up API tests for neutron-dynamic-routing

This patch adds the devstack plugin for neutron-dynamic-routing,
allowing the API tests here to be run in check jobs and under the
tempest framework. It also cleans up the API tests so they execute
properly after being spun out of the main repository.

Change-Id: I0ed82282037fa6c571dd73c8d9900d8e5d0c93c7
Implements: blueprint bgp-spinout

commit_message:
Optimise pip install tasks

Unlike the Ansible apt module, the Ansible pip module does not
recognise a with_items list and process all the items at once.

To optimise the pip install tasks, this patch replaces the use
of with_items with a join filter so that the pip install task
does an install with all the packages in a list, ensuring that
the execution is one action instead of many.

Change-Id: I1df438e88c200ac93e0977566be065a071f2a7a2

commit_message:
Use constraints for coverage job

OpenStack CI supports now constraints in the coverage job - as a first
job to check that the recent changes for zuul-cloner work correctly.

Use constraints for cover environment.

Change-Id: I148a50e3f17fcbf2187898a59b28ea4ed0a827a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/00/343300/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # NOTE(amrith) The setting of the install_command in this location # is only required because currently infra does not actually # support constraints files for the cover job, and while # the environment variable UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is set, there's # no file there. It can be removed when infra changes this. install_command = pip install -U {opts} {packages}

commit_message:
go: fix listObjFiles goroutine leak

Send a cancel channel to listObjFiles, to prevent the possibility of
a leaking goroutines if its consumer doesn't complete.

Change-Id: I94595f1212442e351535ce2dceea4f642f4c871b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/29/341629/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: func (r *Replicator) listObjFiles(objChan chan string, cancel chan struct{}, partdir string, needSuffix func(string) bool) { select { case objChan <- objFile: case <-cancel: return } cancel := make(chan struct{}) defer close(cancel) go r.listObjFiles(objChan, cancel, path, func(suffix string) bool { cancel := make(chan struct{}) defer close(cancel) go r.listObjFiles(objChan, cancel, path, func(string) bool { return true })
deleted_lines: func (r *Replicator) listObjFiles(objChan chan string, partdir string, needSuffix func(string) bool) { objChan <- objFile go r.listObjFiles(objChan, path, func(suffix string) bool { go r.listObjFiles(objChan, path, func(string) bool { return true })

commit_message:
Make generateHostname honor pattern parameter

This patch restores behaviour broken by
I369f79c4258367974eb676cecb6eb1c941803503
The function now returns the pattern if supplied.

Change-Id: I6349555361ab9b12cf2cbd54d130c1979185dd18
Closes-Bug: #1588405

commit_message:
Optimise pip install tasks

Unlike the Ansible apt module, the Ansible pip module does not
recognise a with_items list and process all the items at once.

To optimise the pip install tasks, this patch replaces the use
of with_items with a join filter so that the pip install task
does an install with all the packages in a list, ensuring that
the execution is one action instead of many.

Change-Id: I57f9d2880cff6da2c229f2dfa5340e5c7c608298

commit_message:
Revert "Add AppArmor profile"

ceph-mon is typically deployed under LXC or LXD, where apparmor is
not supported; revert addition of apparmor profile feature as its
currently breaking MAAS+LXD deployments.

This reverts commit d337fdbfd0e0977de94c18d024c1f9490b380279.
This reverts commit cf0f18d59a40f7af2159d6de258eb7f14103435b.

Change-Id: I94b7c7f5dc0245d273394aeb352731f7bffb1c91

commit_message:
Optimise pip install tasks

Unlike the Ansible apt module, the Ansible pip module does not
recognise a with_items list and process all the items at once.

To optimise the pip install tasks, this patch replaces the use
of with_items with a join filter so that the pip install task
does an install with all the packages in a list, ensuring that
the execution is one action instead of many.

commit_message:
Add a fixture for changing facade configuration

It may be useful to temporarily change the facade configuration in
tests by injecting a custom Engine instance (e.g. if one wants to
switch between multiple DB backends).

We have this implemented in the private API. Expose it to external
users as a test fixture.

Closes-Bug: #1548960

Change-Id: Ifa07c9dc42f4d056161367616e562295929b8a16

commit_message:
WIP Remove cinder-volume pacemaker constraints

Initial WIP to bring us to a next generation architecture
as described in the following spec:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/299628/

We need to remove the pacemaker constraints for cinder volume
because the resources the constraints point to, do not exist
in this architecture.

We also need to remove the disabling of the systemd restart
of the cinder-service resources because this prevents
cinder-api and cinder-scheduler to start when run via systemd.
We only no-op the systemd restart of this class.

Implements: blueprint ha-lightweight-architecture
Change-Id: I5f8fe0535ab1a3e73b8e645fa2a0828c8b5de7f2

commit_message:
Add a second proxy-logging middleware entry to swift-proxy

Its absence results in swift using up all the memory available to it when
certain objects are requested, we are not sure exactly what triggers the
problem but we know this fixes it.

Change-Id: Ie4eeaaa83c4e0a181559af639fc13e7fc4939480
Closes-Bug: #1595916
(cherry picked from commit 0b42b6df23f64a7b13d7f809ecd4c1642640e3a7)

commit_message:
Add a second proxy-logging middleware entry to swift-proxy

Its absence results in swift using up all the memory available to it when
certain objects are requested, we are not sure exactly what triggers the
problem but we know this fixes it.

Change-Id: Ie4eeaaa83c4e0a181559af639fc13e7fc4939480
Closes-Bug: #1595916
(cherry picked from commit 0b42b6df23f64a7b13d7f809ecd4c1642640e3a7)

commit_message:
Add support for wsgi framework

Added wsgi framework support to create masakari-api
service using oslo_service framework. Similar to core
openstack projects, config items will be kept at centralized
location.

Refer README.rst to cofigure and run masakari-api service.

Change-Id: Idb0120b8cf3b10642c51b286d82cd0944cad5ca3

commit_message:
Pre-release charm-helpers sync

To begin release testing get each charm up to date with lp:charm-helpers

This also brings the tests up to date with recent changes
to the keystone endpoints registered by the proxy charm.

Change-Id: I96312a20b043857def4a3116c75652f63bc38ac2

commit_message:
Bump oslo.vmware to 2.11.0

The VMware Cinder driver requires a bug fix related to image
meta-data update in the image transfer module of oslo.vmware.
The bug fix is in version 2.11.0.

Change-Id: I677b2b58b729962c83ea7526a49cc4469481cd5a

commit_message:
client_id regex now permits valid fqdn for hostname

The regular expression that was sanity checking client_id
for jobs being submitted to the freezer API wasn't
permitting fully qualified domain names (fqdns) to be
supplied (which it should) so the regex has been updated
to allow this.

Change-Id: I5ec92c9184e74456fc1651653174434cba98eb1d
Closes-Bug: #1570377
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer-api refs/changes/26/343626/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import copy fqdn_regex = "([a-zA-Z\\d]|[a-zA-Z\\d][a-zA-Z\\d\\-]{0,61}[a-zA-Z\\d])" \ "(\\.([a-zA-Z\\d]|[a-zA-Z\\d][a-zA-Z\\d\\-]{0,61}[a-zA-Z\\d]))*" project_regex = "[\\w\\-]+" # Allow all letters, numbers, underscore and minus client_id_regex = "^{project}_{host}$".format(project=project_regex, host=fqdn_regex) "pattern": client_id_regex, "pattern": client_id_regex,

commit_message:
Do not install murano-glance-artifacts-plugin from Glance task

This package is required only by Murano and when Glare for Murano
is enabled. So, we don't need it for Glance at all.

Change-Id: I7dbc42ed11602f06d7424de7a896fb01dd99ffd4
Closes-bug: #1590714

commit_message:
Fix the test test_unwatch_elected_as_leader.

The test test_unwatch_elected_as_leader ensure
that there is exactly one leader election hook exists after
calling watch_elected_as_leader().

But the assertion actually verify that there is only one group
inside the dict _hooks_elected_leader.

This commit fix it by using the actual number of elected
leader hooks: _hooks_elected_leader[self.group_ip].

Change-Id: If4d6192b451f495154c663151000e6071ac4e02c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tooz refs/changes/43/343243/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.assertEqual(1, len(self._coord._hooks_elected_leader[self.group_id]))

power state to "off", but the comment says it sets
to "on". So fix the comment.

commit_message:
Exit with non-zero status on create and update errors

Adds checks for non-zero error status after "openstack overcloud"
commands and exits immediately with an error status.

Change-Id: I3b75aa312d2c18ac9b604f2a1cb4bba45c30c741
Closes-Bug: #1575327

commit_message:
Fix relationships for keystone

Fernet directory (with content) should be
ensured before running any Keystone code.

blueprint: mos-xenial

Closes-bug: #1603929

Change-Id: Ia8079974dc165c4965b935945db95761984a4c94

subject: Optimise pip install tasks
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-18 13:09:19.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/galera_client_install.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_client/commit/d238502a035640b701263102aaa3887faf25a23b', 'message': 'Optimise pip install tasks

Unlike the Ansible apt module, the Ansible pip module does not
recognise a with_items list and process all the items at once.

To optimise the pip install tasks, this patch replaces the use
of with_items with a join filter so that the pip install task
does an install with all the packages in a list, ensuring that
the execution is one action instead of many.

commit_message:
Optimise pip install tasks

Unlike the Ansible apt module, the Ansible pip module does not
recognise a with_items list and process all the items at once.

To optimise the pip install tasks, this patch replaces the use
of with_items with a join filter so that the pip install task
does an install with all the packages in a list, ensuring that
the execution is one action instead of many.

Change-Id: I202b576df32607c23bdcd1a5d23245c0660a0758

commit_message:
Do not install libvirt-python wheel when testing

Add pip_install_options to test vars to ensure libvirt-python is built
from source. A pre-built wheel can be missing libvirt capabilities
from the installed version of libvirt-bin, leading to nova-compute
failing to start.

neutron_rabbitmq_* test variables have also been included as they are
required for the neutron install to complete.

Change-Id: I57e9c50bf835db1ffda2507764a09cb74d7c0884
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_nova refs/changes/41/343441/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: neutron_rabbitmq_port: "{{ rabbitmq_port }}" neutron_rabbitmq_servers: "{{ rabbitmq_servers }}" neutron_rabbitmq_use_ssl: "{{ rabbitmq_use_ssl }}"pip_install_options: "--no-binary libvirt-python"

commit_message:
Make Murano Dashboard log handler configurable

Since https://review.openstack.org/#/c/298653/ is merged,
Murano Dashboard deployment fails if Horizon doesn't use syslog
handler, so we should make it configurable and set default handler
value same as Horizon.

Change-Id: I47342da1212cc6ca6d8eebd6819aa51dcb81dbf5
Closes-Bug: #1593654

commit_message:
Don't always try to create the service image.

This patch makes it possible to create a service_instance resource
without also attempting to upload the image to glance.

This is required because the glance_image resource must be run on the
same host as the glance api service, meaning that it will fail when
trying to create a stand alone manila host.

Defaults to true in order to retain backwards compatibility.

Change-Id: Id863272652db2b01e8d86b94cfd417fa78f7ea1b

added_lines: # [*create_service_image*] # (optional) Upload the service image to glance. # Defaults to: true # $create_service_image = true, if $create_service_image { if $service_image_location { glance_image { $service_image_name: ensure => present, is_public => 'yes', container_format => 'bare', disk_format => 'qcow2', source => $service_image_location, } } else { fail('Missing required parameter service_image_location') }
deleted_lines: if $service_image_location { glance_image { $service_image_name: ensure => present, is_public => 'yes', container_format => 'bare', disk_format => 'qcow2', source => $service_image_location, } } else { fail('Missing required parameter service_image_location')

commit_message:
Use constraints for coverage job

OpenStack CI supports now constraints in the coverage job - as a first
job to check that the recent changes for zuul-cloner work correctly.

Use constraints for cover environment.

Change-Id: I81a985a2049221a8a7ac1f20642137f22847973f

This patch was using an api in neutron-lib that isn't present
in the mitaka branch.

commit_message:
Fix doc warnings

Per Doug's email[0], 'warnerrors' in setup.cfg hasn't actually been
working for some time now, and we've piled up a few warnings. Fix these
before a pbr release to unbreak it gets pushed out and breaks our doc
builds.

[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-June/097849.html

Change-Id: I6576a56234918febb21e7e4860544eb952123c09

commit_message:
Don't configure the Postfix MTA for Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

The bootstrap with Ubuntu 16.04 LTS doesn't contain the Postfix MTA
by default. This commit set the configuration for the Postfix only
in the older Fuel releases where Postfix is exist.  Also, this change
configures Postfix to Local delivery mode only.

Change-Id: I0d47a102ed36b6ab69874cd92735cd46dcf5f593
Closes-Bug: 1603478
Co-Authored-By: Alex Schultz <aschultz@mirantis.com>
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <mmalchuk@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Replace deprecated LOG.warn with warning

LOG.warn is deprecated. It still used in a few places. This updates
those one to use the non-deprecated LOG.warning instead.

Change-Id: Idb0f7ac1f8788ed0a119fb34b56f8ead32e2b85f
Partial-Bug:#1508442

commit_message:
Fix the wrong check condition

Keystone has the code to prevent `None` value to be returned in the
revoke event, but there is wrong check condition that leads to
the `access_token_id` with None will be returned to end user.

Closes-Bug: #1603861
Change-Id: Ifc2908ffb6b8353d24a6416338d8fadb0e0b2a21

commit_message:
[cli-ref] update warning message

The word "automatically" sometimes makes people confused.
This patch changes the message to more accurate.
Tool update: https://review.openstack.org/343153/

Change-Id: I6a5f051cfe0ef54cb2843dfbb03dc9064bdec955

commit_message:
Added full support of snmp v3 usm model

We used to only support partial of the snmp v3 usm model. This patch
adds the full support.

Change-Id: I3da8b19dea6a5ed3b0625d615ed27856046aa240
Closes-Bug: #1597618
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/45/338645/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Implements ProcessMonitor in the haproxy driver

The ProcessMonitor class will monitor spawned external processes.

This patch enhances the HaproxyNSDriver class (v2) to utilize the
external_process module in order to monitor and respawn the haproxy processes
if and when needed.

With this patch the LBaaS agent (v2) will load external_process related options
in order to take a configured action when haproxy process dies unexpectedly.

Closes-Bug: #1565801

Change-Id: I420ca20b2620487909885e0e9f08dae60ebec2bf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/66/327966/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.agent.linux import external_processfrom neutron_lbaas._i18n import _, _LI, _LWHAPROXY_SERVICE_NAME = 'haproxy' def __init__(self, conf, plugin_rpc, process_monitor): super(HaproxyNSDriver, self).__init__(conf, plugin_rpc, process_monitor) self.process_monitor = process_monitor pid_data = self._get_state_file_path(loadbalancer_id, 'haproxy.pid') pid_file = pid_data.split('/')[-1] pid_path = pid_data[:-len(pid_file)] self.process_monitor.unregister(uuid=loadbalancer_id, service_name=HAPROXY_SERVICE_NAME) pm = external_process.ProcessManager(uuid=loadbalancer_id, namespace=namespace, service=HAPROXY_SERVICE_NAME, conf=self.conf, pids_path=pid_path, pid_file=pid_data) pm.disable() def callback(pid_path): conf_path = self._get_state_file_path(loadbalancer.id, 'haproxy.conf') sock_path = self._get_state_file_path(loadbalancer.id, 'haproxy_stats.sock') user_group = self.conf.haproxy.user_group haproxy_base_dir = self._get_state_file_path(loadbalancer.id, '') jinja_cfg.save_config(conf_path, loadbalancer, sock_path, user_group, haproxy_base_dir) cmd = ['haproxy', '-f', conf_path, '-p', pid_path] cmd.extend(extra_cmd_args) return cmd pid_data = self._get_state_file_path(loadbalancer.id, 'haproxy.pid') pid_file = pid_data.split('/')[-1] pid_path = pid_data[:-len(pid_file)] pm = external_process.ProcessManager( uuid=loadbalancer.id, default_cmd_callback=callback, namespace=namespace, service=HAPROXY_SERVICE_NAME, conf=self.conf, pids_path=pid_path, pid_file=pid_data) pm.enable(reload_cfg=False) self.process_monitor.register(uuid=loadbalancer.id, service_name=HAPROXY_SERVICE_NAME, monitored_process=pm)
deleted_lines: from neutron.agent.linux import utils as linux_utilsfrom neutron_lbaas._i18n import _, _LI, _LE, _LW def __init__(self, conf, plugin_rpc): super(HaproxyNSDriver, self).__init__(conf, plugin_rpc) pid_path = self._get_state_file_path(loadbalancer_id, 'haproxy.pid') # kill the process kill_pids_in_file(pid_path) conf_path = self._get_state_file_path(loadbalancer.id, 'haproxy.conf') pid_path = self._get_state_file_path(loadbalancer.id, 'haproxy.pid') sock_path = self._get_state_file_path(loadbalancer.id, 'haproxy_stats.sock') user_group = self.conf.haproxy.user_group haproxy_base_dir = self._get_state_file_path(loadbalancer.id, '') jinja_cfg.save_config(conf_path, loadbalancer, sock_path, user_group, haproxy_base_dir) cmd = ['haproxy', '-f', conf_path, '-p', pid_path] cmd.extend(extra_cmd_args) ns = ip_lib.IPWrapper(namespace=namespace) ns.netns.execute(cmd) def kill_pids_in_file(pid_path): if os.path.exists(pid_path): with open(pid_path, 'r') as pids: for pid in pids: pid = pid.strip() try: linux_utils.execute(['kill', '-9', pid], run_as_root=True) except RuntimeError: LOG.exception( _LE('Unable to kill haproxy process: %s'), pid )

commit_message:
Set QoS on cloned volumes

Not sure where/when it happened yet, but it looks like the QoS setting for
clone volume has been dropped.

This patch fixes it back up by checking the new volumes type info for
QoS settings after clone.

Change-Id: I48a3d0e5f15417235a2041535c0c671fbaafb0a8
Closes-Bug: #1589187
(cherry picked from commit f57447223a359d64f47795d9ff57a68a8481c0ed)

commit_message:
Add first 4 ha tests from acceptance

- Add 2 tests with neutron vlan: cinder for volumes/ceph for images
and ceph for volumes/swift
- Add another 2 tests with neutron vlan: cinder/swift/ephemeral and
cinder/ceph for images/ephemeral

Change-Id: I17da7f66592a521b824e2c5b19dfb34e5f4b102b
Related-Bug: #1524772
(cherry picked from commit 8f29346c31d4450f00f59ef2b3e75ee44145b3d6)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/12/321512/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def check_ceph_image_size(remote, expected_size, device='vdc'): ret = remote.check_call("df -m /dev/{device}* | grep ceph |" " awk" " {size}".format(device=device, size=re.escape('{print $2}') ))['stdout'] if not ret: logger.error("Partition not present! {}: ".format( remote.check_call("df -m"))) raise Exception logger.debug("Partitions: {part}".format(part=ret)) assert_true(abs(float(ret[0].rstrip()) / float(expected_size) - 1) < 0.1, "size {0} is not equal" " to {1}".format(ret[0].rstrip(), expected_size)) @logwrap def check_cinder_image_size(remote, expected_size, device='vdc3'): ret = get_mongo_partitions(remote, device)[0].rstrip().rstrip('G') cinder_size = int(ret) * 1024 assert_true(abs(float(cinder_size) / float(expected_size) - 1) < 0.1, "size {0} is not equal" " to {1}".format(ret[0].rstrip(), expected_size)) @logwrap

commit_message:
Move MySQL Galera within composable services

This patch just moves the Puppet code into puppet-tripleo.
A future iteration will be to move parameters within the service
template.

Closes-Bug: #1601853
Depends-On: I7ddae28a6affd55c5bffc15d72226a18c708850e
Change-Id: I51a05dbf53f516b200c146b35529ce563ce9ac7b

commit_message:
Use jsonutils instead of ast for loading the service catalog

AST! Never AST!

The service catalog set from auth_token middleware is a json blob not a
python blob and should be decoded as such.

This brings up the problem that the service catalog specified in the
tests is not actually valid JSON. In future I'll attempt to change this
over to using the auth_token fixture instead of a custom environment
dictionary.

Change-Id: Ic9ab68f7d41d19d3595a3ddbbb2e233f57ef52c8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware refs/changes/73/336973/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Fix unit test for n1kv_vem agent
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-18 10:08:50.000000000', 'files': ['spec/classes/neutron_agents_n1kv_vem_spec.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron/commit/0ce66292ac176c6f61edc92a9e967a4ea87fd5c0', 'message': 'Fix unit test for n1kv_vem agent

default facts (and exactly puppetversion fact) are required for the test.

Change-Id: I8eef6453d5024cbb6e3264bd682339a927103249
'}]
commit_message:
Fix unit test for n1kv_vem agent

default facts (and exactly puppetversion fact) are required for the test.

Change-Id: I8eef6453d5024cbb6e3264bd682339a927103249
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/48/343548/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: let :test_facts do shared_examples_for 'neutron n1kv_vem agent' do it 'should have a n1kv-vem config file' do is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/n1kv/n1kv.conf').with( :ensure => 'present', it 'install n1kv-vem' do is_expected.to contain_service('openvswitch').with_notify(['Package[nexus1000v]']) is_expected.to contain_package('nexus1000v').with_notify(['Service[nexus1000v]']) is_expected.to contain_service('nexus1000v').with_ensure('running') context 'with local file vem rpm' do let :params do { :n1kv_source => 'vem.rpm' } end it 'verify dependency' do is_expected.to contain_package('nexus1000v').with_source('/var/n1kv/vem.rpm') is_expected.to contain_file('/var/n1kv/vem.rpm').that_requires('File[/var/n1kv]') is_expected.to contain_file('/var/n1kv/vem.rpm').with( :owner => 'root', :group => 'root', :mode => '0664' ) end end context 'remote vem rpm' do let :params do { :n1kv_source => 'http://www.cisco.com/repo' } end it 'verify dependency' do is_expected.to contain_package('nexus1000v').without_source is_expected.to contain_yumrepo('cisco-vem-repo').with( :baseurl => 'http://www.cisco.com/repo', :enabled => 1 ) end it 'execute reread config upon config change' do is_expected.to contain_exec('vemcmd reread config') \ .that_subscribes_to('File[/etc/n1kv/n1kv.conf]') context 'verify n1kv.conf default' do let :params do { :n1kv_vsm_ip => '9.0.0.1', :n1kv_vsm_ipv6 => '::3', :n1kv_vsm_domain_id => 900, :host_mgmt_intf => 'eth9', :portdb => 'ovs', :fastpath_flood => 'enable' } end it do is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/n1kv/n1kv.conf') \ .with_content(/^l3control-ipaddr 9.0.0.1/) is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/n1kv/n1kv.conf') \ .with_content(/^l3control-ipv6addr ::3/) is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/n1kv/n1kv.conf') \ .with_content(/^switch-domain 900/) is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/n1kv/n1kv.conf') \ .with_content(/^host-mgmt-intf eth9/) is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/n1kv/n1kv.conf') \ subject: Use the adapter instead of the client in tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-05 19:36:46.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/tests/unit/test_base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/ea59511cc2e6dc9598a2debbb91926f14da5d624', 'message': 'Use the adapter instead of the client in tests

Both the V2.0 and V3 clients create managers by passing in an instance
of the _KeystoneAdapter class. Is seems reasonable for the tests to do
the same things to keep everything consistent.

Change-Id: I06d256e71105fdad3f4d182a53a6887617b4cffe
'}]
commit_message:
Use the adapter instead of the client in tests

Both the V2.0 and V3 clients create managers by passing in an instance
of the _KeystoneAdapter class. Is seems reasonable for the tests to do
the same things to keep everything consistent.

Change-Id: I06d256e71105fdad3f4d182a53a6887617b4cffe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/35/337835/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.client = client.Client(session=session_)._adapter

commit_message:
Removing .erlang.cookie before rabbitmq bootstrap recreates it

In kolla-kubernetes environment rabbitmq bootstrap process fails when
.erlang.cookie already exists, the issue is consistently reproduced when
using persistent storage PV/PVC. This PS prevents this type of failure.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I3509650b1c11aa45cd5ae2d8eea6523201bfb1de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/58/339758/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ -e "/var/lib/rabbitmq/.erlang.cookie" ] then rm -rf /var/lib/rabbitmq/.erlang.cookie fi

commit_message:
Use flavor name for checking flavor existence

Flavor existence check with ID returns the flavor even though
that flavor is deleted. Using flavor name is more consistent
with deleted flavors and works across openstack releases
reliably

Change-Id: I563fab6eeb849405bc520c1cae425a1ff0d56ff2

commit_message:
Update JS dependencies

* React from 15.1.0 to 15.2.1
* LoDash from 4.13.0 to 4.13.1
* jQuery 3.0.0 to 3.1.0
* React-router from 2.4.1 to 2.5.2
* Added async-props 0.3.2
* Added react-slider 0.6.1

Implements blueprint react-router

Change-Id: I6374dc12c3b616bb5251ba60ea065f3d45af798f

subject: Support Keystone Domain specific files
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-07 13:41:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/9e848e9363be5ff46f5c89bb68b47f1ddbd506eb', 'message': 'Support Keystone Domain specific files

Currently, it is not possible to make use of Keystone Domain
specific settings. Such as different domains using different
LDAP servers or SQL.

To enable for example domain ACME - domain settings would be
put into:
{{ node_custom_config }}keystone/domains/keystone.ACME.conf

Change-Id: I23620978c618dd4a3598d7cb74c3e9cf8c2394ac
